DOOM Eternal is what should have been the DOOM of 2016. *STORY*: DOOM Slayer returns to take revenge on the forces of hell and save the Earth. You can see ID Software's efforts to give Eternal a better and more interesting script, but it's just not its point.Nevertheless, there are some quite well achieved references that resolve doubts regarding the classic DOOMs. *GAMEPLAY*: Eternal has the best FPS gunplay of the eighth generation of video games, with plenty of playable elements and lots of fun.On the contrary, although the platform areas are better achieved than in the previous one, there is still a necessary improvement. *GRAPHICS*: The engine is a visual and technical marvel and artistically magnificent. *SOUND*: The soundtrack fits perfectly and the sound effects are well achieved. *INNOVATION: Eternal DOOM doesn't innovate like DOOM (2016), but it doesn't have to. New playable elements, new races, new plot... This is the real return of the DOOM Slayer.

Supera en prácticamente todo a su entrega anterior.id software nos prometió mas enemigos, mas feroces e implacables... y lo cumplieron con creces. Mejoraron la jugabilidad agregando la habilidad de "Carrera" o dash como todos le dicen, lo que hace que podamos esquivar ataques mas feroces y salir de aprietos pero sin romper el juego... y si que es útil, los enemigos son tan c4brones que un Caballero del infierno o un Pinky del juego anterior no son nada comparados con estos. Los enemigos al ser mas jodidos que antes, entonces ya cuentan con la mecánica de los puntos débiles, los cuales es obligatorio saber utilizar si o si, por que aparecen tantos enemigos que si no los ocupamos y no nos aprovechamos de esos puntos débiles entonces nos aplastaran sin problemas. En este caso el juego nos fuerza a utilizar todo nuestro arsenal, no es terminarse la munición de un arma y cambiarla por otra, hay que utilizar todas.La cantidad de munición a siro reducida a mas o menos un 40 por ciento en comparación del juego anterior. Digo, la escopeta pasó de tener 60 cartuchos a 24 como máximo. Eso hace que tengamos que utilizar la motosierra mas a menudo y no hay que mortificarse al utilizarla ya que aun que nos acabemos la gasolina el primer uso siempre se recarga con el tiempo. Agregaron granadas normales y granadas congelantes, sumado de un lanzallamas que nos sirve para conseguir armadura. Y a la superescopeta le agregaron un gancho que nos sirve para aventarnos hacia los enemigos.Eliminaron la clásica pistola y he visto reseñas en los que se quejan de eso, pero siendo realistas ¿cuando la han ocupado en el juego anterior? Su uso era muy puntero y se limitaba a el principio del juego ya que en niveles avanzados no servía de nada, y en este caso me alegro de que la retiraran, ya que si no lo ocupábamos en el juego anterior y siendo que en este caso los enemigos son mas difíciles y rápidos ¿Serviría de algo realmente? Algo que si considero negativo es que ahora el cuerpo a cuerpo ya no puede debilitar enemigos con el, por que ahora hasta un simple zombi o poseído soporta todos los golpes que les des, pero al menos los aturde un poco.... eso y que hay zonas donde hay una especie de líquido morado que nos limita el movimiento, nos movemos muy lento, y ni si quiera podemos saltar, mientras que todos los enemigos se pueden mover con total libertad. - En cuanto a sonido. El soundtrack es espectacular, transmite lo que necesita y es frenético sin llegar a cansar.Los sonidos en general están bien, pero hay unos detallitos que no me gustaron, como por ejemplo: el sonido de disparo de la ametralladora pesada, se escucha como simples clicks y no transmiten fuerza como en el juego anterior y que los gemidos de dolor del Slayer apenas se escuchan, por lo que pasan desapercibidos (a menos que hayamos activado los sonidos clásicos, pero rompen con la inmersión y la estética del juego). La interfás en los menús no me gustó del todo, ya que es muy agresiva y demasiado lleno de detalles sumados con una fuente para el texto algo cuadrado... a "O" parece un rombo :/ aunque en los textos largo al menos utilizan otra fuente. En cuanto al HUD... se ve bien pero como las cosas vitales son tan pequeñas al final no las vemos para nada cuando la cosa se pone fea y mucho menos las escuchamos cuando recargan, ya que tanto ruido durante el combate hace que simplemente no se escuchen y para acabarla de amolar, casi no se ve la carga de las granadas o del lanzallamas ya que los iconos se ven muy traslucidos, y al no poder verlos entonces utilizarlos es casi una apuesta. Otro punto a destacar es la introducción de los niveles maestros, los cuales son los mismos del juego pero desde el principio te encuentras a enemigos bastante duros... te aparecen 2 tiranos apenas empezando los niveles.A pesar de que los niveles maestros son muy buenos, todavía hecho de menos el modo "Arcade" Lo único que detesto del juego es que si tenemos internet inestable y si se pierde la conexión con Bethesda.net entonces el juego se pausa y nos pone un letrerote en nuestra cara y odio que interrumpan la acción de una manera tan invasiva. O que tarda una eternidad en cargar los niveles si le cuesta conectarse a los servidores.De a perdis lo hubieran hecho como en Borderlands 2, el cual te ponía un letrero a una esquina de la pantalla y no pausaba la acción para nada. P.D. No mencione nada del modo Battlemode ya que al parecer está mas muerto que el multijugador del juego anterior ya que nunca encuentro partida, así que no lo he podido probar :/ Y si en un futuro se les ocurriera agregar algún multijugador pues preferiría que intenten imitar un Quake.

An absolute mind blowing hell of a ride and return to the Doom franchise! Doom Eternal is basically more of Doom 2016 but bigger, better, and crazier! The delay is sure did payoff! So much amazing content plus more in one epic sequel! This game is indeed this generation's version of Doom II Hell On Earth!

Pretty much Doom 2016 with more mechanics, more gore, and more demons. Now, if you haven't played Doom 2016 prior to this game, do that first ($20 on Steam and they have really nice sales) as you would not be able to return to 2016 once you've picked up Doom Eternal. Systems like the new gib system are extremely satisfying, you can watch as pieces of the demons you are mowing down scatter in a fountain of blood. The addition of the blade on the Doomguy's arm spices up some of the glory kills with even more blood. The new weapon mods are pretty much the same as the ones in 2016, except the useless mods were all switched out for more interesting ones. Progression comes in weapons with weapon mods and mod upgrades then masteries. Additionally, your sult can be upgraded with praetor tokens and some kind of shard (I forget the name).Now, Eternal has many design decisions that clearly separates it from its predecessor. Eternal has a generally less gritty and dark theme compared to 2016 and has much more in bright ammo or health pickups. There is a decent amount of platforming though you do this knowing that any moment, you will enter a new arena in which another epic massacre of demons will ensue. Finally, the addition of mechanics such as the blood punch, flame belch, and new grenades serve as a way for the player to manage their resources.Thus far, I have but one complaint for the game which is the challenges. As a bit of a completionist, the challenges requiring me to glory kill from specific angles on demons which only appear once or twice kind of sucks. This is not really a reason to not buy the game though. The game is good. You should play it.

Doom Eternal give you what you expect in an action FPS. Hell, in an FPS. If you want a fast paced shooter where you massacre stuff with high mobility this is what you need. Just point and shoot, with very few cut-scenes and dialog.

The game isn't what I expexted it is far better then anything I expected It always keeps fresh because the devs add masterlevels wich are remakes of the the levels you played in the game but always with a harder difficulty level. The story is also in th right amount it is the right amount so that it won't disturb you

The game is fantastic. Doom guy's face is kinda revealed, we got more story that got me interested in the game, the gameplay is just ETERNAL. The only thing I didn't like was the weapon pickups. In Doom (2016) they had a place, you picked the weapons from dead soldiers or other places but here most of the weapons are like an old game. Don't get me wrong I like it but it feels a little out of place in my opinion. This game is just Awesome!Haven't finished it, I played only 9 hours and those hours I really enjoyed.For the dev team and the game testers out there THANK YOU for a polished product!

Don't listen to these entitled pubescent Bethesda troll haters in the reviews! This game is a masterpiece! And in my opinion, if not better than Doom 2016. The combat is defined and fast paced, enemy AI are relentless (a lot smarter than 2016), graphics are amazing and well optimized and the story is decent (hence why I gave it a 9 instead of 10). For those who said in their review that this game is slow paced, you're on crack cocaine or imagined you were playing Minecraft! This game is brutally fast and challenging (played on Nightmare)! The adding of the dash into game opened up a whole dimension of the game that Doom 2016 didn't have. Like holy **** You can dash half way across a map, shot a grenade into a Cacodemons mouth while in mid air, perform an execution on it mid air spraying blood and guts everywhere and then dash back without touching the ground while 40 different demons are trying to snipe you out of the air! So visceral and exciting! Sure there are some quite times in-between killing demons and finding secrets, but that will happen when you destroy ever single entity in site!! The area will be death with silence (I digress)! And just like Doom 2016, the head banging thrashing industrial metal composed by Mick Gordon tides with the Doom slaying carnage just as well as the prequel. I'm telling you guys if you're into fps, carnage, a challenge with a great soundtrack and graphics, pick up this game. An instant classic! ( P.S. the multiplayer is decent as well)
Best game i played for last 3 years! Guns, speed and tones of demon meat - things you'll get!

Great game. Yes, it is different than Doom (2016), it has more survival and lots more fast-paced gameplay. There's sort of rthythm in killing, doing glory-kills and chainsawing thrash mobs to gain ammo and health. I finished the game at ultra-violence, it was fun. I think all the boss fights were pretty easy. Only thing i didn't like was those marauders and their dogs... But i killed them too. Arm blade to the face!

A great step ahead from doom 2016. This game is really, really good. The gunplay is perfected from 2016 along with the Level Design. The Story isn't too great, but for a doom nerd, it's okay (me, Its a doom game, you don't really need a good story TBH) Again, it seems they really took it to the next level coming from doom 2016. Also, new demons bring a fresh experience to this game. Some complaints, however: limited ammo, a certain annoying enemy (Marauder), and no snap map. If you love FPS/DOOM games, get this game. If you want to get into those games, play this. It's not too difficult. To conclude this review: everything you really need for a good doom game (Level design, demons, guns/gunplay) are here, and better than ever.

Not as well rounded and polished as DOOM 2016 but still exhilarating fast paced action that keeps you reaching for any and every edge you can get if you play it at an appropriate difficulty. There is slightly more storyline than the previous game, but it only serves to hype up your next encounter. I believe the skill ceiling is higher and they challenge you more in this game, however at some points combat is somewhat over-complicated in enemy variety. You need to use certain weapons/abilities to defeat certain enemies, however so many enemies can be thrown at you sometimes that they block shots for eachother and all you can do is run and use explosives. Multiplayer got hammered in DOOM 2016 but it was actually fun. The multiplayer in this one isn't interesting and isn't good enough to keep people playing.

Review: Absolute masterpiece. Please ignore every other review on the user section, they're all bad and wrong. If you are a player who likes to rip and tear until it is done, you will absolutely love doom eternal. This game is amazing, adding new elements that doom 2016 never could even muster to offer at the time.If you hated this game just because ammo was scarce, use your chainsaw more. If you hated this game because of the "Jumping Puzzles" you literally are incapable of using your brain to see a jump that you are provided with a double jump and 2 dashes to complete. If you hated this game because of the secrets, you don't have to get all of them, most are optional. You thought this game was too hard? This game is built off of resource management, you gotta learn how to do that. If you haven't played this game, start reading from here. The game's bones are resource management and fighting. If you would like the standard doom eternal experience without going crazy over that one collectible, just don't get it at that moment and wait until you have exploration upgrades to find it or fast travel. The levels are gorgeous. Like literally, look out your window or go outside to a big suburban town, then come back inside and play more doom eternal. Tell me that you aren't asking "How the heck did earth get this way?" Anyway, the visuals are amazing. The specs are really living up to what they said they were. Multiplayer... is a disappointment. The battlemode in this game is the only bad point I have. They didn't fully flesh it out/make it fun, which is why most people stick to the campaign, the best thing in the game. One more bad point that I think more people should be aware of: not exactly bad but just a bug. If you have cheat codes equipped while doing a campaign mission you've never done before that has a slayer gate, disable all cheat codes and the slayer key will appear. This bug has hindered me many times, but literally everything else in the game makes up for it.

This game deserves to be played, it fixes all the issues the 2016 Doom has, buffed weapons, gameplay, story, and so much more. You will enjoy every minute of this game from start to finish. But do make sure you have a strong enough CPU to handle this game.

I've never taken the time to review any game before, but I felt that this game is worth the time to share my opinion. Let's first start with the not-so-good aspects.-The platforming can be frustrating at times and seems like a big departure from other Doom games and more appropriate for a different game type.-Weapon pickups are not nearly as immersive as Doom 2016. Overall things are far more arcade-like, which will be a turn off to some.-Another bummer is that the game currently has only one multiplayer mode. Here's to hoping id software will listen to fans and bring back at least DM and TDM.-While I appreciate id's efforts to make the game more engaging by adding more mechanics, it can get a little overwhelming at times, but it isn't a big deal considering the game's combat is superb. Now on to the good.+The combat is, in my opinion, very addictive and will really get your heart rate going, especially at the higher difficulties. Quite frankly, this is some of the best FPS action I have experienced since Half Life 2.+The game is insanely well optimized and looks great at 1440p.+The enhanced traversal mechanics add a nice extra layer to the combat loop.+There is a nice variety of enemies, each requiring a unique approach within the combat loop.+The level design is interesting and a nice upgrade from Doom 2016's comparatively cramped levels. While it is not perfect, the excellent combat encounters and presentation more than make up for the game's minor gripes. If you enjoyed Doom 2016's fast paced`game play and are open to Eternal's additions ahead of time, I think you won't be disappointed.

Doom 2016 was my favorite shooter and one of my favorite game of the 2010s its slick and fast pace gameplay was amazing and incredibly fun, but now with the release of Doom Eternal it takes everything Doom 2016 did right and made it a lot better. To start off the level design on this game is horrific (in a good way) on a visual storytelling point, everything looks amazing to look at and it catches the esscence of doom beautifully, the levels offer a lot of mobility to the player and makes the level design look more 3 dimentional they are fun and great. The platorming is a little bit of a double edge sword its so fun just going around swinging through poles jumping and climbing walls (the design of these are beautiful), but sometimes it gets a bit tedidous and repetitive it doesnt feel bad most of the time. The gameplay is **** amazing the introduction of dashes and jumps just make the game so interactive and they give a lot of mobility to the player that fit like a puzzle piece with the amazing level design the options that you have just make the experience a lot better with the chainsaw and the weapon mods overall the gameplay feels like a more free version of 2016 with a bit lighter but brutal tone. The soundtrack is really good not the most amazing but really good overall. The ripping and tearing along with the level design and the fun packex in here, Doom Eternal is a great videogame and an eternal doom experience. Like a wise melon once said: "Im feeling a strong to a decent 9 on this one" (i also love the collectibles they are so fun to collect)

It's good.Compared to DOOM 2016 it is much more visually interesting, has been injected with more "STORY," customization, depth of complexity, and love.If you thought 2016's combat was perfect this may not be for you.This appears to be where most negative reviews creep in (along side people who are having technical problems).Where 2016 was all about mobility and freedom to engage how you like, Eternal has refined systems that could easily fall unused from 2016 (the chainsaw, equipment usage, and additional movement systems) and made them core elements that you will be using almost every fight.Unlike 2016, you will be running out of ammo and need to chainsaw a trash mob to get back in the fight, and because fights can have MANY more enemies fighting you at once with faster traveling projectiles you are much more likely to be hit, encouraging you to glory kill almost wherever possible. Larger enemies are much more of a threat and will take considerable focus to bring down, but also have additional weak spots that in many cases can be removed to limit their options or reduce their effectiveness. In summary, combat has been given more layers of depth, but with less options to approach it. I can understand there are quite a few players who this will only cause frustration to, and make it feel like an inferior sequel, but when it clicks I firmly believe it is a strict improvement on its predecessor.

Short review: Doom Eternal is better than Doom 2016, but ID needs a third Doom game to reach a golden mean. Long review: Doom Eternal came to me as a surprise on many fronts, even after an extensive advertisement campaign and fanbase hype. Story continuation, drastic gameplay and verticality changes, unconventional multiplayer, countless easter-eggs and customisation options. It was certainly not the classical Doom or Quake game a devoted player became accommodated with, similar to Warcraft becoming a flashy MOBA game, but the question of whether the change was alien and uncalled for is quite challenging to answer. First, the story itself. Having completed the campaign several times and analysed all of codex entries, the key word I would apply to the storytelling is "deus ex machina". Doomguy, previously a frenzied character who just kills demons, suddenly became an omnipotent god-like hero and nemesis for 3 different races apart from humanity. Very limited, flashback-oriented backstory as to how he came to be, why did everything happen on Argenta, was it because of him, why was he granted the blessing of Divinity machine, and so on, and so forth. ID might have pushed a bit too hard into a new territory this time, resulting in more question than answers and implying that a new game will tell the player more about the whole Hell, Earth and Heaven (not Urdak) ordeal. But the setting itself had laid a solid foundation for next instalments of the franchise, leaving obvious gaps and suggestions as to what to await next. We will wait and see how the story, yet unfinished and still vague, unfolds itself. Secondly, the multiplayer. There might not be much to say here. It is fun and engaging, not necessarily fresh in terms of the theme, but most definitely better than classical and mind-numbing deathmatch we grew sick of for the past several decades. I was satisfied with it during Quake arenas already. Progression and customisation however leave very little room for replayability of Doom multiplayer, when the only thing keeping you at the game is a new cosmetic item or an avatar icon. I would love to see more unconventional gamemodes introduced to the setting, featuring a sound progression and reasonable loadout customisation, as strategy brings longer lasting fun than one-dimensional arcade. And finally, the gameplay. Oh boy, where should I start. Long story short, it is excessive in everything. Movement, upgrades, puzzles, sprites, events, armaments, even a whole player hub with easter-eggs and collectibles. For a Doom universe, and for the grim and silent character of Doomguy, it might be too much of unnecessary details interfering with the life-long mission of punching demons in the face. On the one hand, it brings character to the game, a comment many might have said in their reviews, on the other hand however it feels too alien to be introduced to a player in such volume. The game feels like an experimental sandbox aimed to identify and reimagine the icon of Doom, too ambitious for its own good, too fast paced, too completionist-oriented, too naive with its puzzles, too desperate throwing players into arena pits to uncover new mechanics and combos one would not bother considering in a less stressful scenario. It is a step in the right direction, for sure. But as I have already stated, we need a third game to nail the tempo, right inbetween two extremes: Between arcade and ambient grimdark, a child of Doom and Quake, the earlier Doom and Quake. Or if you like, a mature and self-confident version of Doom 2016. I would still like to give the game a score of 8/10. I might be a Doom fanboy after all, but the game is still solid, even with its flaws. Everything works seamless, even if hectic, and the atmosphere is all I could wish for. Doom Eternal feels like an early-twenties metalhead who likes to experiment with his habits, but if he decides on his life mission just right and applies enough pressure and work to become his very best, then something magical will certainly happen.
I cant stop playing this game, IMO it is a must-play for all. The enemies are varied and interesting, the gameplay is challenging but fair, and glory killing is fun as all hell.

This game is a truly arena fps masterpiece,It's everything a Doom fan could have asked for,it's frenetic and challenging,colorful and diverse.It beats the previous goat Doom 2016 in every single aspect,level design,difficulty,demon design,bosses,longevity,replayability,better multiplayer mode and most of all,the game has a **** of new features.Heck,even the HUD is way better.Regarding the graphics part,well it's ages better then the previous game and that's thanks to the new IDTech7 which makes geometry detail wonders especially on pc. The game is the most optimized pc title at the very moment and it runs smooth as hell on every pc,PC MASTER RACE baby.Furthermore the game could be compared to a Soul-like game in terms of difficulty when that is set to Ultra Violence or Nightmare level,and that makes the game even funnier with Mick Gordon's soundtrack that basically tells you 24/7 to rip and tear until the end.Doom Eternal is my goty 2020 for the very moment,waiting for Cyberpunk 2077 to challenge it.Furthermore I have a comment on the negative reviews on this site and regarding this game,don't even bother reading those who gave this game a straight 0,people that give such a low mark to such a game are either retarded or fortnite snowflakes who know nothing about arena fps games and what they are supposed to be like.Give a try to the game and play it more than 10 hours and you will get to see that all the negative reviews here are pointless pile of complacent trash.This is all for now,rip and tear brothers and sisters,rip and tear until it's done.Thanks ID Software for this masterpiece of a game,the best fps we Doom fans could have ever asked for.

If you only played Doom 2016 and never played the original Doom games, you may not understand why the game took the art direction it took. It is more colorful and more cartoony... Just like the original Doom was. Doom was always a violent and gorey game, but in it's origins, it wasn't a dark game. It had very colorful and bright aesthetics, which took full advantage of the VGA graphics of the time. Doom Eternal pays tribute to that aesthetic, and honestly, it all around seems to be targeted at pleasing the fans of classic doom. The extremely arcadey gameplay is strong evidence of that, that is Doom and Quake in a nutshell. Extremely high mobility, labirinthic level design, violence and brutal difficulty. Doom Eternal checks all those marks for me. On the higher difficulty levels, the game is merciless. It is a power fantasy, but you are only rewarded with the satisfaction of that power fantasy when you understand and master all the mechanics and movement of the game. Many people seem to be turned off by the jumping. While it isn't technical and precise like I would like it to be (Quake-style strafe jumping is more my alley when it comes to fast movement), I don't think the platforming elements are nearly as bad as people are making them out to be. It's not difficult, once you get the hang of it, it becomes really enjoyable too. Overall, I had many criticisms about Doom 2016 as a sequel to Doom 1, 2 and 64, and most of them were addressed by Doom Eternal. It is a true tribute to Classic Doom fans and I appreciate that.

TL;DR: The Doom 2 to 2016's Doom 1. Harder, faster, more technical with a greater focus on weapon switching, equipment usage and mobility. Doom Eternal is an amazing, breakneck fast, punishing example of what id Software, and the FPS genre in general, is capable of. It is a game that sets the pace of combat, and expects you to keep up and doesn't give a damn if you can't, and apparently people have an issue with this. As a whole across my entire Ultraviolence playthrough, there were maybe 5 encounters that I would consider questionable in terms of difficulty, and 2 of those were optional. The combat is different to 2016, with a greater focus on equipment usage and movement compared to the previous game, with enemies that require more strategy and thought then "Apply Gauss Cannon/SSG until dead" and arenas that, near the end of the campaign, become outright dangerous. The story felt very Doom, taking itself just seriously enough whilst also acknowledging just how silly it all is, and the soundtrack is... Well, 2016's OST was not a one-off smash hit for Mick Gordon. This is not a game for everyone, and a lot of Doom 2016 fans are going to be disappointed it isn't 2016-2. It is a very different beast, but in the best way. In a way, it's the perfect homage to Doom 2, in that it takes the formula of the previous title, and does its own thing with it. Marauders can eat it tho.

i’m going to start this off by keeping it plain and simple. THE GAME IS GOOD. BUY IT. i’ve been anticipating this game since release. while there was a delay, i knew it would be worth it. id software has created a phenomenal game that will undoubtedly rule my top games of 2020. the first hour of doom eternal required some getting used to even after playing countless hours of doom 2016. all of the abilities, mechanics, and weapons became overwhelming for me in the beginning. i felt so overwhelmed with all the new features in the game that i was kinda disappointed at first, but as soon as i figured out how the game works, i could NOT stop playing. the game feels AMAZING. the fluidity of all the weapons and abilities in ur arsenal in use during every fight is sooo satisfying. the new demons provide a new challenge, and keep the game refreshing despite how repetitive moving around an area and shooting demons sounds on paper. the level design is SOLID. packed with hidden secrets, collectibles, and colorful, dynamic environments that lead me to taking breaks nearly every level to just sit and observe the world around me. the game is loaded with some insane boss fights that feel like what should be in a hack n slash game like god of war, but somehow it was put in a fps, and somehow it works, and it works wayyy better than i would ever imagine it to be...

And an even better soundtrack than the last game.Fast and relentless. One of the best single player shooters ever made. One of the best FPS games to come along in years. Playing this game is like re-living the thrill of shooters in the 90's and early 2000's. It's like a mix of classic Doom and Quake 2, albeit with far more movement options, and SPEED. Holy cow, this game is fast, and brutal. Unlike the 2016 game, levels are designed to feel  a lot more organic, and less explicitly broken down into arena lock down's. They are still  a thing, but they don't feel as obvious. They are also, harder, but not unfairly so. While enemies pack a bigger punch, they also react much more to being hit. The difficulty also eases up as you play, particularly as you upgrade your suit and guns. Once you've unlocked the full toy box  and have the full movement and weapon range, everything just clicks. Battles are intense, exhilarating, and keep you firmly in the moment like so very few shooters do. The aesthetic of the game is about as perfect a modernization of classic Doom as it gets. Enemies are visually familiar, but with far more attitude than in 2016. The environments, likewise, are jaw dropping, presenting epic and varied vista's. This is Hell on Earth as it was always meant to be. An interesting thing about the environments is that they are a large part of the reason why the game feels so much like a 90's shooter. Despite the movement mechanics being so advanced, the flow and visual design of each section captured the spirit of those older titles almost perfectly. And then there's the sound track, which is far more riff based than the 2016 "glitch rock" focused score. Add the OST in with the visuals, and this is quite emphatically the most "Metal" game around. My only real issues with the game come down to some levels having an over reliance on platforming segments, and one particular enemy type. I won't spoil who, but I'll say that he's far too contrary to the rest of the games mechanics for my taste. Some people have had difficulty juggling the games multiple systems (Fire for armor, chainsaw for ammo, glory kill for health), but again, I personally thought they flowed exceptionally well together once your abilities were all in line. This means that the early half of the game may be a bit of a rough edge for some, though I wasn't personally put off by it. It's well worth persevering through though, even if you feel like it's initially a lot to take in. My excitement is based on the single player here. I have yet to try out the game's Battle Mode, but honestly; it's worth the buy just for the campaign alone. It's one of the easiest games to recommend, especially if you're an old FPS fan.

The game is very good! It has cool fights with many enemies and for all enemies you need another tactic. There are many good action and not so easy campaign. I think it's one of better chapter of Doom, but it's only my opinion. Sory for my not ideal English.

Alright, going to be honest, I had never played a Doom game before this one, so while I might not be as emotionally invested in the series as others who have played the others in their youth, I can definitely say that this game got me so obsessed with the series as a whole that I went and got all the others, just to continue the experience. I had assumed there wasn't any story and just came in with the expectation of shoot, kill, repeat, and while yes that is a lot of it and it's damn fun, I ended up becoming invested and curious about the story of everything, naturally, had to go play and watch for more information. That being said, fantastic level design, gameplay, and to be honest, I actually love the added colours, while some say it takes away from the brutal experience (compared to 2016), I think it only highlights it, gives each atmosphere a bit more character, makes it so much more pleasing on the eye, and makes me want to just stare at every new thing I came across because of how beautiful it is. Not sure what else to say so, I love the painting with Daisy on the wall, it is adorable

First I want to make an awnser to negative reviews. While some have constructive criticism, i cannot understand other arguments that I will list: -Doom eternal is too cartoony, so it isn't doom what? Have you ever played doom and doom 2? Doom at its core is a fps in a cartoony gore setting with over the top guns, demons, and story. It's centered primarly arround gameplay and the more cartoonish (if you can call it that way, boy do not play nintendo games if you think that is cartoony) art direction makes for way clearer level design and arenas, which so many shooters fail at today. If this is bad then enjoy your visually bloated realistic game where you have trouble seeing an ennemy cause it blends with the props. To me, the only people who think doom eternals visuals are a betrayal to doom are the people who only played doom 3 and doom 2016, which are great in their own way but do not feel like OG doom and more like their own take on the series. If you prefer this take, cool but don't you dare saying that doom, at its core is a serious, mysterious and sometimes scary shooter. play dead space if you want especialy that. -Then some people complained about always being low on ammo and getting blocked in the map. my advice: get good. No seriously, the game has a steep learning curve in the first 5 hours, but once you get and master all your weapons, upgrade your ammo stock and learn how to master this game's movement and flow, then it becomes the best fps ever made. It's on the game's fault though if it doesn't let you experience that before the 4th level but boy it is rewarding, give it some time. After beating the game on ultraviolence, i can say i was never killed in a cheap way, never ran out of options and was always invested in the combat. Okay that out of the window, I can confidently say it's my favourite fps of all time, 30 hours in. I played a lot of fps, hell we installed unreal and quake on the highschool computers so we could make lans, i played all the half life, red faction, call of duty, star wars dark forces, all the doom games so i have something to compare. That's why this game felt so good for me, it managed to bring back passion and novelty in a genre that died 10 years ago.  It made me feel so powerfull yet always on the brink of getting owned, game me many options that force you to always change weapons, re evaluate your strategy, prioritize ennemies and manage your ammo, it's the same feeling as in doom 1 and 2, but on steroids.The story, as always is over the top and all cutscenes (i think there is less than 40 minutes of cutscenes in the game, all are skippable and sparse in the last thrid of the game) feel right in the doom mindset, some are hype, some expose you to some lore or some are just there to make the levels breathe, often near a boss or a big fight. The lore is totally skippable to but is surprisingly deep and well written, too bad it is not as well included in the levels as doom 2016. Thouh the levels are more focused on secret finding and exploration, some being more open ended which is a great breath of fresh air and more akin to the first doom games' level design. The levels are also filled with main encounters and smaller ones which also makes the level's flow constant while doom 2016 was more: big adrenaline surge where you find demons and then boring coridors with exposition via dialogue. Overall, the level design feels more confident and know what it wants while the last game kinda didn't know where to sit. I can't run out of good things to say about this game, but i can run out of bad things to say about it: first, i would have preffered having all the weapons more quickly. second, The marauder is a hot pile of garbade and i hate this **** he plays devil may cry and wants you to play his game, except you are playing doom. Third: hopefully i didn't watch any trailers or marketing **** on the game, because seeing those after having finished the game, i can say they spoil a lot of things, like some demons returning, the final boss (which in the game is forshadowed only near the end) and a lot of gameplay elements and maps. Such a tragedy when i look back at the feelings i had when discovering that in game, please don't watch promotional material of this game, the bfg 10k level's first 10 minutes then you will know if you wanna buy this game or not. Conclusion: To me, it's a brilliant return to the roots, in terms of game design/level design phylosophy but also a clear evolution for the series and the fps genre as a whole. Playing other fps will feel kinda boring after this and the game immerse you so much in the massacre you're commiting that you'll have to take a deep breath and a good piss in order to return to normal life after you take it down. Excellent game, would gladly buy a solo expansion with more maps that use the full arsenal you get in the final stages of the game. would have been goty if mario bros 2 didn't exist.

Well, I liked the game. It's fast-paced with strategy playing a key component. You cannot just go around spamming one weapon, you need to think, act fast and make multiple decision at the same time. Yes, initially I found it challenging (I died many times during the gameplay) but now got used to it. Regarding the story, I like how it ties in doom 1,2 and 64. Music is brilliant. I highly recommend the game but at the time before buying look at a few gameplay videos on youtube or other streaming platform and then decide if it's for you.
Pure ID software product.No surprises. Delivers exactly what it was supposed to. Best fps.

If you liked DOOM 2016 you will definitely like DOOM Eternal. One of the best games i have ever played. The guns are fun to use. The dashing and monkey bars are very cool. And whoever thought of a grapple hook on a shotgun is a genius.

This game is awesome! One thing that kind of bothered me was the *weapon presentation*. When you first come across another weapon, it is just floating, while in Doom 2016, it was presented to you very well. For example, the combat shotgun in Doom 2016, when you come across it, you see it in a soldier's hands, while in Doom Eternal, you see it floating. It ruins the _imersion_. But The game compensates this with the *platforming*, *music*, *gore*, *gunplay*, *story*, *visuals*, *level design*, and *upgrade system*. This, for me, it set an example of contemporary fps games, just like Doom 2016, but improved almost every feature of it. If you value this genre, this title is essential. Another upgrade is the *game size*. It went from almost _70 GB_ of space to _40GB_, which made it effortless and quicker to download, and also saved me a *lot* of SSD space. It is, overall one of the finest fps games of 2020 for me. I highly recommend it to anyone who wishes a challenging, yet fun, video game!

Background - I beat game on nightmare. This is one of the best shooter campaigns I've played in 20 years. The game is a true evolution from the first one, and a masterclass in game design. Every gun/ability is a part of a tool-set that rewards the player for learning how to use it by providing the ability to eviscerate enemies with surgical precision at lightening speed.. I'm sure those looking for a mindless shooter may not appreciate that aspect of the game or its skill requirements. For those people, I'd honestly recommend passing on this,  For everyone else, this is a must buy. The only thing that stopped me from rating it a 10 was the lack of a more robust multiplayer. While fun, I question Battlemode's longevity and balance. For those unaware. Battlemode is where one player plays the slayer fighting against two player controlled demons.

I can easily say that Doom Eternal is the best first-person shooter I have ever played, surpassing the previous best; Doom 2016. After years of waiting for Eternal, I had pre-ordered it for my PS4, but couldn't wait any longer and impulsively bought it for PC on March 19 and played it until 5 in the morning. The whole game feels like the trailers, with the amazing visuals making you feel like the Doomslayer, also known as the biggest badass of videogame history, and complemented by that killer soundtrack, it really makes Doom Eternal one of the best videogame experiences of all time. I love this game so freaking much and so should you.

This bad boy kills the FPS genre with even MORE aggressiveness than the last game. Most of the FPS games I've played is "hide behind and wait for the other guy to stop shooting". Every DOOM game (except doom 3, which on it's own, isn't bad, but if it's DOOM. it sure as hell shouldn't be horror.) knows how to make an FPS game which makes it worth your time. I hate a lot of people giving this game a negative score when they straight up say that they had an hour or two of game play, or are very nostalgic and don't like "Mario jumping", low ammo or how one demon out of 34 demons in the game managed to piss you off. If you seriously can't handle the demons, just switch to a lower difficulty, there is no judgment, you play how you want. (you can also use cheat codes in any mission you want, if you found them in-game)

Doom eternal is one of the best fps game I have ever played and it exceeds your expectations after playing Doom 2016. I was waiting for this game this was like the most anticipated game for 2020.The level design is incredible .The dashing and jumping mechanics are great.The weapons are better than Doom 2016 The music is great. Music forcibly pumps adrenaline and gives you feels of the game.The lore of every boss is great.The bosses were easier than 2016 Doom And the most annoying enemy was marauder he was so **** tanky and can deflect every attack .If you like Doom franchise you will absolutely **** love this game

Without a doubt this the best DOOM game i ever played (i did play all of them, excluding the console spin offs).Doom 2016 was merely a warm-up for the symphony of violence that is this game, yes it is hard (played on nightmare mode, but it is quite doable).I never write reviews, but the thing that made me write this is the jarring reviews from more than a few edgelords on youtube and the internet as a whole. I agree that it can be soul-crushing but it is fair every time, and finishing every inch of the game comes with a true feeling of PRIDE AND ACCOMPLISHMENT.Marauder (shield axe guy) got a lot of flack due to peculiar timing needed to defeat him.. once you get his rythm he is super easy.. don't give up.Argument can be made that it is only about killing demons, but if that bores you doom is not for you. It is made to be gameplay focused. And it stay fresh to the very end. Will play again and again. Corona is temporary, but DOOM is eternal. Stay safe my dudes!

Doom Eternal is one of, if not the best FPS I’ve ever played. Great combat flow, intriguing bosses, and a **** ton of weapons to use. I’m only giving it a 9 for these reasons.1. Only online mode at launch is battle mode, it’s fun, but gets old after a while. Would have been nice to just have slayer battles again.2. There is more than the max on some story upgrade items, which defeats the purpose of 100%ing the game and really triggers my OCD.3. **** MARAUDERS, THESE **** HEADS ARE SO **** ANNOYING, THEY ARE EITHER THROWING THIER DAMN AXES AT YOU, SHOOTING THE **** OUT OF YOU, OR SUMMONING CLIFFORD THE BIG RED DOG TO BITE YOUR ASS. AND WHEN YOU FINALLY GET AN OPENING, A **** ZOMBIE COMES OUT OF NOWHERE AND THROWS YOU OFF. **** MARAUDERS.Besides those reasons, Doom Eternal is a great game  with a long, enjoyable story, great combat mechanics, and a whole lot of ass to kick.

This game is a lot better than DOOM 2016. It's way more challenging on the same difficulty levels, game is more enjoyable in every aspect. Right after I finished it went back to DOOM 2016 to make sure I wasn't overhyping myself and IT IS truly better. Combat feels way more fun, weapon juggling, chainsaw refueling gives you super fluid gameplay that 2016 can only dream off. It's like they merged Unreal Tournament and Quake's DNA into this one. Finished DOOM 2016 twice, this however is way more replayable. Story is fun, it's not a movie, just some quick cutscenes that can be skipped if you really don't care about the story. People seem to forget that you can skip it altogether if you're here only for Ripping and Tearing enemies. I guess people can't enjoy games that aren't super simple. It's solid arena shooter with great levels, good platforming, awesome guns and hell it's a DOOM game in 2020.

Its diffrent than 2016 doom. It changed many things for the better. No weapon or equipment feels useless and no weapon is an "i win" button (man the gauss cannon from 2016 was OP AF) . The combat is much more demanding from the player and way faster. Upgrades and runes are also more balanced and searching for secrets is for me much better than the way doom 2016 did those. Oh and about the plaforming. Usually i hate platforming with all of my body. I hate platforming games i hate platforming in action games and i despise platforming in shooters and i never felt  annoyed by Ethernals . It was a just a break from ripping and tearing that i needed and the longer you play the less of it there is imo. Now i don't think the game is a 10/10 im rly only giving it that score cuz there is no way that the 7,6 it has now is in any way shape or form reflecting on how good this game is its at the very least as good as doom 2016. I think some folks just expected it to cure cancer or something and they are dissapointed that is "just" a doom game

I've put over 100 hours into Doom 2016 because it's so fun to replay. I love getting into the flow state and strategizing in real time. Doom Eternal took some adjustment, as many of my old strategies did not work out the box. Once I got the new flow, I grew to love it. There's an insane amount of work that's been put into this game. Every single demon serves a purpose, and they really push you to understand how to take down each type. At first, this annoyed me--I wanted to just pound everything with the same weapon. But Eternal forces you to think harder. You have to prioritize enemy types and learn (often the hard way) which ones to save for last, vs which to take out immediately. Once that prioritization was in my brain, I had to learn the new rhythm of ammo/health/armor management. In a way, Eternal makes this easier than 2016: there are infinitely spawning fodder that can be farmed for resources. Fire = armor, glory kill or ice bomb = health, chainsaw = ammo. Mixing and matching the various mechanics to recoup was really effective. However, it has an odd side effect: the new mobility options make the player so fast that you can typically run away from a big boy who's beating you up and just keep running until you've found enough fodder to be at full health/armor/ammo. This was useful in allowing me to turn the tide of a battle that was going poorly. However, one thing I liked about 2016 was that the options for recovery were limited--you basically needed to not get in too  much trouble in the first place. That made 2016 better at forcing high performance at all times. In Eternal, you can screw up, then panic and run laps until you're OK again. They did introduce things like whiplashes and marauders that seem really good at interrupting a panic lap, which I appreciate. But in the end, I felt Eternal's new mechanics made it so forgiving that they had to make the battles that much more hectic. In the end, I loved finishing Eternal. The scale was jaw dropping, and the demon designs were fantastic. It runs incredibly well. There are some things I'm lukewarm on. Platforming was hit or miss. Some sections I legit enjoyed, others were tedious and not well designed. Also, there are too many meters to track when the game is this insane. I absolutely cannot keep track of whether my ice grenade, frag grenade, chainsaw, or blood punch were ready to go. In practice, there's never enough time to look and think "is my blood punch ready?" Instead, you just go on instinct. I think cooldowns work better in slower games. The final boss fights were way more fun than the spider mastermind in 2016. However, no boss fight in Eternal was as good as Cyberdemon from 2016! But in the end, I loved Eternal. It's made some great innovations to the genre and I'm excited to see its influence on future FPSs. Ultimately, I only docked one point from a perfect score because I have died multiple times in ways that felt unreasonable. For instance, when there's so much going on that I literally cannot see a demon through all the on screen effects, then it kills me, it's a bit frustrating since I could not possibly have avoided it. The best deaths are the ones where I'm left thinking "Oh if I'd done something different I could have avoided that!" Most of the time, Eternal does that well, but more than 2016 I found myself dying from unavoidable stuff I never saw coming.

I was a big fan of Doom (2016) when that came out, despite finding the last act of the game to drag a fair bit. So naturally my expectations were quite high, but Doom Eternal has exceeded these high expectation. Doing the first run on Nightmare was the best single player FPS experience I've ever had. The combat is brutally fast, chaotic and violent. You're always short of health and ammo, and need to adapt to the game's rules in order to survive. Quickly you start getting into a certain rhythm and learning efficient ways to take out the disgustingly cool demons. The art design is amazing, animations very creative and gory, the soundtrack even heavier than in the first doom. The guns sound and feel incredible. i dare say that this game has the coolest weapons of any game in recent years (if not ever). The locations you visit are all visually distinct now (unlike the previous game), and this coupled with enemies and weapons continuously being introduced throughout the game keeps it interesting and exciting. The game is a bit longer than Doom 2016, but due to these improvements doesn't feel like it's dragging at all towards its end.I can see how the platforming can be boring to some, but I didn't mind it as it, along with the hunting down of secrets and doing the challenges, provided a good break from the pure annihilation of the big fights. The Nightmare difficulty is quite brutal, and sometimes frustrating, but it pushes you to learn how to play which only makes you feels more badass by the end. If you're familiar with FPS games I definitely recommend playing on this setting (the difficulty can be changed at any time in the settings menu).It feels like some enemies are straight up OP, but then you discover weapons and strategies that are even more OP against them. It's a great feeling. I did encounter several bugs during my run, but nothing gamebreaking. Overall it was a great game and amazing experience. I strongly recommend it to everyone who likes fast, skill-based games. To me this is an early contender for GotY.

This game is a masterpiece. Every aspect of this game was meticulously crafted to create the most metal, intense, blood-pumping experience ever. This game could easily become the best shooter of 2020, if not the best shooter of the decade. And to clarify, we are talking about Half-life Alex here. Trust me, it's that good. Every aspect, from the visuals, gameplay, and design were implemented to create the most satisfying game I have ever played. When it comes to action-packed gameplay, I have yet to see an FPS that surpassed Doom Eternal. Even I was skeptical about this game. When I first saw the updated interface I was very angry. The cool thing is, is that these developers are very good at their job. They overhauled the interface to what it is now. Even if it is still apparent and full of color, I think it works well. I say that confidently, even though  I am huge nitpick when it comes to interface. I can even make the interface red, thank God. This properly shows how much Id cares for their fans. Not that bitter, ignorant, and frankly thoughtless crowd of people who claim that 2016 was better. Honestly, I don't think it's even possible to convince them otherwise, considering that their reviews are only filled with the same three bad things about the game over and over again. It takes a lot of closemindedness to come to the conclusions that they do. People like that don't want to try anything new and hate having to think when they play a game. Spoilers, you actually have to think when you play this game. I find it almost impossible to say 2016 was better than Eternal. It almost makes me think that these people didn't play the game all the way through, and got overly frustrated on one aspect of the game you could easily ignore. I don't know why the loot economy was so hard for people to cope with too. Just chainsaw and flame belch occasionally. It's the easiest part of the game, honestly. Finally, a doom game that makes you manage resources and think a little bit. If only more games were like that. A relatively small part of this game that people love to complain about is the platforming. The platforming just was a brief and fun way to bridge the gap between various locations.  For once the thing separating different arenas wasn't just a hallway. It seems that things that made the game awesome, like verticality, more weapons, and more demons seemed to be the common complaint listed in these negative reviews. Doom Eternal improved upon all aspects of 2016, and I mean all of them. All of the true flaws of this game like the purple sludge, and occasional encounters with the marauder, were newer smaller problems that Doom Eternal created on its own. For you to hate this game, you needed to already hate all platforming, any form of cutscenes, even the short and good ones, and anything more colorful than a couple of greys and oranges. Luckily these diehard, lazy, close-minded reviewers are in the vast minority. In short, this game is very very good. Nothing, under no circumstances, should keep you from buying this game. Yes, this is incredibly different than 2016, but also immensely more enjoyable. Id outdid themselves by a landslide in every way. This is, by far, the best game I have ever played. But honestly, the multiplayer was pretty wack.
Норм игра, стоит своих денег!Очень атмосферная игруха, покупайте.ТОПЧИК!!!
It did everything doom 2016 did but more and better, i don't see why people are struggling with the difficulty and the the arcade feel is a bad thing.

Awesome game improved on 2016 in almost every aspect from combat, movement, enemy and level design. Some of the bad reviews are extremely misleading. Low ammo is not much of a problem in this game if you switch your weapons, don't spam ammo like a moron and accurately target the weak points of the demons. The chainsaw fuel generously regenerates quickly, chainsaw ammo is abundant in the world and as you level up their are ammo increasing upgrades. The complaints of platforming is also weird considering the game sparingly uses it and is simply expanded on 2016 platforming levels

So many whiners giving low ratings because of the new mechanics and the story cutscenes.  These kind of people are never satisfied.  If they had produced literally just more Doom 2016 levels, they would have complained that they didn't do anything, or that it's just more of the same, or boring.  Hell, they even say this is boring.  I've played 20 hours so far, and I'm a completionist, so I'm getting every item and taking a deep look at the lore and story.  I have been playing this since 1993, and to see where they took the story makes me feel so fulfilled.  Calling it a "satanic cartoon" is pretty ridiculous.  Do you realize how NOT realistic the premise is to begin with?  What were you expecting?  It is a fake story, but a very cared and loved one to both devs and fans alike.  I personally feel like I'm getting SO MUCH MORE than I wanted from this game.  Those complaining about graphics being worse...I can't even.  I am playing this on PC with a 2080 Ti on the highest settings on a CRG9 49" UW...5120x1440 at 120 FPS...no lag...the textures and details are astounding and the best graphics of any game I own PERIOD.  While other games offer these settings, it's usually at the cost of some performance.  id knew this and really made this work for such a fast-paced game. Bottom-line, you can't please everyone..that's for sure.  It's harder with the new mechanics, but, to me, in a good way...and I really feel like I have to work to be UNSTOPPABLE.  In DOOM 2016, I feel like I was too strong..and the game was much easier.  I feel a reward for playing intelligently and being strategic...and the speed is INSANE.  The level designs are MASSIVE and fit arena style playing, which...I mean, do I even have to say that id's games are all this way?  Sigh...just watch videos to see if you want it or not.  This reviewer has been a fan of id since Wolf3D, and I am SO happy to be seeing where they are today.

The game is simply amazing, the optimization is PERFECT. No glitches, bugs, framerate drops since DAY ONE.The music is on point with the gameplay, and shooting to enemies is satisfying af.One of the best FPS game I've ever played, if you're insecure about purchasing it or not... DO IT, NOW.

id software has done it again!Superb gameplay, awesome music, big guns! I mean what more can you ask for? id's like: "Here is a gun, kill everything that moves."I'm like: "Thank you very much, don't mind if I do!" 10/10!
